thread.title: Hundreds in Tucson protest Trump travel ban
thread.title_full: Hundreds in Tucson protest Trump travel ban

author: Kaila White , The Republic | azcentral.com
title: Hundreds in Tucson protest Trump travel ban

organizations.name: w. congress st. janice yu of tucson news now

text:
Organizers anticipated about 1,000 people Tuesday at the protest against President Donald Trump's executive order. Get the latest breaking news at azcentral. (Photo: azcentral.com) 
About 400 people were chanting and holding signs outside U.S. Sen. John McCain's Tucson office about 5 p.m. Tuesday to protest against President Donald Trump's executive order banning refugees and citizens from certain Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S.
The crowd was "very peaceful," according to Tucson Police Department Sgt. Pete Dugan.
Organizers anticipated about 1,000 people and the crowd may grow, as the protest was planned for 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. outside McCain's Tucson office at 407 W. Congress St.
Janice Yu of Tucson News Now posted videos showing the expansive crowd on both sides of the street.
Just to give you an idea of how many people are downtown right now protesting Trump's refugee executive order. #tucson @TucsonNewsNow pic.twitter.com/yB3Ik0Vfrs 
— Janice Yu (@JaniceYuNews) January 31, 2017 About 1,300 people marked that they were "going" to the Facebook event and another 2,900 indicated they were "interested" as of Tuesday afternoon.
"Let's send a clear message that we expect a permanent end to all discrimination against immigrants, refugees and other vulnerable people," the event description states. People posted on social media using the hashtag #NoBanTucson.
Organizers said the protest will support McCain's opposition to the executive order and press him to take action against it.
AZCENTRAL
Hundreds protest Trump's immigration ban at Phoenix Sky Harbor airport
McCain also has offices in Phoenix, Prescott and Washington, D.C., where he should be this week since the Senate is in session.
Jeniffer Zimmerman, founder of All Bodies Rise Yoga , organized the protest but has been overwhelmed by how much it has grown, according to her friend, Joel Feinman, who is now helping to organize.
Organizers planned speakers for the event, including Nate Terani, a Muslim veteran, and Zaira Livier, who founded Tucson-based Latinas for Bernie Sanders. Feinman also may speak; he was a public defender and ran for Pima County attorney last year.
"The more articles that Senator McCain reads from his home state, the more TV stories he sees, and the more radio stories he listens to from his own state talking about people's popular emotional and patriotic opposition to the president's horrific immigration policies, the more likely he’s gonna be to stand up to those policies," Feinman said.
McCain on Sunday blasted Trump's temporary refugee ban on Syria and six other Muslim-majority countries as "a confused process" that will boost the terrorist Islamic State's propaganda efforts.
Post by johnmccain .
